transcripts.text: Here's a guy who thinks he has a question that atheists fear.

Okay, today we're going to talk about the one question that all atheists fear, or at the very least they really hate to try and answer this question.  I've been debating going back and forth with atheists for just over a year now and sometimes I feel like catnip and I feel like they think they're the cat.  They see a Christian and they want to pounce on me and play just like they do with everybody else.  And they always pose this question and the question is, give me the evidence that Christianity is true, that Jesus is God, things of that nature.  So, you know, thinking they're honest, I'm going to go down the evidence and I'll cite the scientific evidence, the historical evidence, the archaeological evidence, How could there be scientific evidence of a God?

Science studies that which is observable and testable.  How can you test for the existence of a God or test whether Jesus is a God?  It's not clear to me that there is even a clear definition of a God.  It seems to be defined as something which is not physical, but if it's not physical, what is it?  And what would it mean for such a thing to be observed and tested in a scientific way?  How can you have historical evidence of a God?  And how do the historical accounts of Jesus demonstrate that He is a God?  Even if Jesus really performed every miracle described in the Gospels, it wouldn't follow that.  Jesus is therefore a God.  Even if Jesus really healed the sick, turned water into wine, and rose from the dead, the fact that He had those powers isn't evidence that He was all-powerful.  And again, since it's not clear what a God is even supposed to be, it's not clear what would constitute evidence that Jesus was one.  I've never seen any archaeological evidence that Jesus existed at all.  There's testimonial evidence, but there are no surviving artifacts, like the cross, despite all of the people who claim to have some bit of it, or a contemporaneous painting or sculpture.  The closest thing we have to archaeological evidence of Jesus is the Pilate Stone, which is a stone with Pontius Pilate's name inscribed on it.  that looks as though it was probably created during Pilate's lifetime.  And that's not really even evidence of Jesus, it's only evidence that at least one person mentioned in the Gospels existed.

Third-party evidence is hearsay.  It's the weakest possible form of evidence.  Hearsay evidence that Jesus was a God is essentially that someone heard someone else say that Jesus was a God.  Nobody should find that even remotely convincing.  And you can't claim fulfilled prophetic evidence without applying hermeneutic contortionism to the Old Testament messianic prophecies.  Jesus didn't really fit the Old Testament description of the Messiah at all.  As the New Testament scholar Bart Ehrman says in his book, How Jesus Became God, it's very surprising that people came to think of him as the prophesied Messiah, given the fact that, as far as we can tell, Jesus did nothing during his lifetime to make anyone think he was this anointed one.  That is to say, he did not come on the clouds of heaven to judge the living and the dead, he was not a priest, and he never raised an army and drove the Romans out of the Promised Land to set up Israel as a sovereign state.  Apologists try to rebut this by asserting that it's all somehow metaphorically true, which they have to assert because of how obvious it is that a face value reading of the prophecies about the Messiah clearly doesn't match the attested life of Jesus.  Statistical probabilities.  By statistical probabilities, I suspect this dude means the application of Bayes' theorem.  William Lane Craig believes that Bayes' theorem proves that reports of Jesus' resurrection are more probably explained by a miracle than by hallucination, mistaken identity, fabrication,  etc.,  given the evidence at hand.  I did a video about why this is silly that I'll link in the description, but suffice it to say that you can't say that a miracle is more or less probable than any other explanation unless you can assign a value to the probability that a miracle occurred, which you can't without a clear and coherent explanation of what it means to say that a god exists, let alone what it means to say that one performs miracles.
I'll cite the eyewitness accounts of over 500 people that saw the events.

Apologists often mention the 500 people as though they have 500 separate accounts.  That would be impressive if it were the case.  Alas, it is not.  What they are talking about is what Paul says in 1 Corinthians 15 6.  He says that Jesus appeared to more than 500 brothers and sisters at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have died.  Every Christian who brings this up wants us to treat this single assertion by a single person, Paul, as though it has the same evidential weight as 500 separate, independent, mutually corroborating testimonies.  This is very silly.
I mean, 25,000 pieces of parchments and documents that are original and show that the text has never been altered.

First of all, there are not, in fact, 25,000 manuscripts that have never been altered.  Most of the manuscripts counted in the 25,000 are translations, and translation, I think, should count as alterations.  The number of manuscripts in the original Greek is only 5,800.  The 5,800 Greek manuscripts are not all complete.  Many are very small fragments and they do, in fact, contain inconsistencies.  Bart Ehrman says in his book, Misquoting Jesus, that even scribes who were competent, trained, and alert sometimes made mistakes.  Sometimes, though, as we have seen, they changed the text because they thought it was supposed to be changed.  For example, when they came across a passage that appeared to embody a mistake that needed to be corrected, possibly a contradiction found in the text, or a mistaken geographical reference.  or a misplaced scriptural illusion.  Ehrman gives the example of a difference between the 4th century Codex Vaticanus and most other manuscripts.  He says that in the opening of the book of Hebrews, there is a passage in which, according to most manuscripts, we are told that Christ bears, Greek phaeron, all things by the word of his power.  In Codex Vaticanus, however, the original scribe produced a slightly different text with a verb that sounded similar in Greek.  Here, the text instead reads, Christ manifests, Greek phaeron, all things by the word of his power.  So the manuscripts are not all identical.  But even if every manuscript were perfectly identical, it's not clear how that would be evidence that Jesus was a God.

I mean, I go through mountains and mountains of evidence, only to have them say at the end, well, that doesn't really count.  That's not really evidence.  You still don't have any proof that God exists, and you certainly don't have any proof that Jesus is God.

I can understand how that would be frustrating if they just said that without explaining it, but I just gave some pretty thorough explanations why your purported evidence is weak at best and not at all what you seem to think it is at worst.  Well I looked at the evidence and saw that in some cases it does not exist, and even when it does, it is the weakest form of evidence.

But an atheist will just sort of brush it all aside and say that it doesn't really count.  Well, I came on the one question that all atheists fear and no atheist can answer by accident.  Because one day I was so flustered I said, okay, show me the evidence you have to prove that God does not exist.

Well, let's assume your definition of God is the definition used by mainstream apologists like William Lane Craig.  Apologists will commonly say that God is a timeless and spaceless being and or a disembodied mind.  Since being a being, as far as I can tell, is to have extension and or location in space-time, a timeless, spaceless being is a contradiction in terms.  Since a mind, as far as I can tell, is a process carried out by some form of body, a disembodied mind is a contradiction in terms.  Assuming I'm correct in my understanding of what a mind is and what a being is, this constitutes proof that such a thing as a God does not exist.

And I got an answer like this.  It was a blank stare.  They don't have evidence that God doesn't exist.  None.  They never have.  And the very thing they accuse Christians of having, which is blind faith, turns out is exactly what atheists have.  They have no evidence to support their position.  They have no evidence to support that God doesn't exist.  So they live with a blind faith that God doesn't exist.

Whether this statement is true also depends on what kind of atheist this dude is talking about.  Lots of atheists are agnostic atheists.  They are folks who merely lack the belief in a god rather than affirming the non-existence of a god.  You don't need faith to lack a belief in something.  To everyone who helps me out on Patreon, you're a big help.  Thanks so much.
